required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasound-Guided Erector Spinae Plan Block in Patients Undergoing ESWL
clinical_study.official_title: The Analgesic Efficacy of Ultrasound-Guided Erector Spinae Plan Block in Patients Undergoing ESWL

brief_summary.textblock: Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is widely used in the treatment of urinary tract stones and is generally applied to outpatients. To achieve fragmentation in ESWL, shock waves must be applied with sufficient power and time. Providing effective analgesia during this procedure is crucial to the success of the procedure. Erector Spinae Plan Block (ESPB) was first described in 2016 and, it is frequently used for postoperative analgesia in urinary system surgery. This study aimed to investigate the efficacy of ESPB in patients undergoing ESWL.

secondary_outcome.description: Pain will be evaluated with a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) score of 0-10 (0= no pain and 10= worst imaginable pain)

arm_group.description: Ultrasound-guided erector spinae plane block with 10 ml %0.5 bupivacaine and 10 ml %2 lidocaine
lidocaine 5% gel and 800 mg ibuprofen intravenously

intervention.intervention_name: Bupivacaine HCl 0.5 % in 10 ml and 2 % lidocaine in 10 ml
intervention.description: Erector spinae plane block, 30 min before the ESWL procedure.

intervention.intervention_name: 5 % Lidocaine Topical Gel and 800 mg ibuprofen intravenously
intervention.description: 5 % Lidocaine Topical Gel and 800 mg ibuprofen intravenously, 30 min before the ESWL procedure.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- American Society of Anesthesiologist's physiologic state I-II patients undergoing Extracorporeal Shockwave Lithotripsy
Exclusion Criteria:
- chronic pain
- bleeding disorders
- renal or hepatic insufficiency
- patients on chronic non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications
- emergency cases

reference.citation: Yayik AM, Ahiskalioglu A, Alici HA, Celik EC, Cesur S, Ahiskalioglu EO, Demirdogen SO, Karaca O, Adanur S. Less painful ESWL with ultrasound-guided quadratus lumborum block: a prospective randomized controlled study. Scand J Urol. 2019 Dec;53(6):411-416. doi: 10.1080/21681805.2019.1658636. Epub 2019 Sep 9.

Yayik AM, Celik EC, Ahiskalioglu A. An unusual usage for ultrasound guided Quadratus Lumborum Block: Pediatric extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy. J Clin Anesth. 2018 May;46:47-48. doi: 10.1016/j.jclinane.2018.01.016. Epub 2018 Mar 26.
